choices.text: Arrector Pili Muscle

questions.text: ___________________ Demarcates Hair into Upper & Lower Hair Follicles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arrector Pili Muscle

 

Option C. Arrector Pili Muscle:

 

  • It is a small band of smooth muscle that connects the hair follicle to the dermal tissue.
     
  • It plays a role in the thermoregulation mechanism by causing hair to stand erect ('goose bumps') when contracted, which can provide insulation.
     
  • This muscle's attachment point to the hair follicle demarcates the boundary between the upper and lower follicle, with the upper portion being associated with the sebaceous gland and the pilo sebaceous unit above the muscle attachment, and the lower portion being below this point, encompassing the hair bulb and the region where active hair growth occurs.
     
  • Upper and lower hair follicles are separated by the arrector pili. The portion above arrector pili constitutes the upper hair follicle while the portion below constitutes the lower hair follicle.
  • Attachement of Sebaceous Gland divides Upper Segement into Upper Infundibulum & Lower Isthmus. Apocrine Gland attaches above Sebaceous Gland. Lower Segment is divided into Upper Stem & Lower Bulb by Adamson`s Fringe.

 

 

Structure of hair follicle

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stem Cells:

  • They are primarily located in the bulge region of the hair follicle, play a crucial role in the regeneration and growth cycle of the hair but do not serve as a demarcating boundary between the upper and lower segments of the hair follicle.

 

Option B. Huxley’s Layer:

  • It is part of the inner root sheath and is involved in the structural support and shaping of the growing hair shaft. It does not demarcate the hair follicle into upper and lower segments.

 

Huxley’s & Henley’s layers are part of Inner Root Sheath (IRS)

 

As can be seen in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D. Adamson’s fringe:

  • This refers to the point where the inner root sheath disintegrates and the hair shaft emerges, marking the transition from the non-keratinized to the keratinized part of the hair shaft within the follicle.
  • It is not considered a demarcation point between the upper and lower hair follicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arrector pili muscle's insertion point demarcates the boundary between the upper and lower segments of the hairfollicle.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.3

choices.text: Anagen is the period of Active Growth of Hair
80-90% of Hair is in Anagen at One Point of Time
Telogen Lasts for 3 Years
Kenogen is a State of Latency

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement among the following statements regarding Hair Cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Telogen Lasts for 3 Years.

 

Option C. This is false statement:

  • Telogen, the resting phase of the hair cycle, typically lasts about 1 to 4 months, not 3 years.
     
  • During telogen, the hair does not grow but stays attached to the follicle until it is pushed out by the growth of a new anagen hair.

 

  • The phases of the hair growth cycle include Anagen, Catagen, Telogen, and sometimes Kenogen.
     
  • Anagen is the phase of active hair growth.
     
  • During this time, cells in the root of the hair are rapidly dividing, and new hair is growing.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anagen:

  • Anagen is indeed the active growth phase of hair follicles and can last several years.

 

Option B. Anagen.

  • At any given time, about 80-90% of hair follicles are in the anagen phase, which can last from two to six years or longer for scalp hair.

 

Option D. Kenogen:

  • It is a phase not always recognized in the literature but refers to the period of the hair cycle where the hair follicle remains empty after hair shedding and before the start of a new anagen phase.
     
  • This phase is essentially a gap or a latency period in the hair cycle and is characterized by the absence of a hair shaft in the follicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Telogen is the resting phase of the hair cycle, typically lasting about 1 to 4 months, not 3 years, while anagen is the active growth phase, and the majority of hair is in this phase at any point in time.
     
  • Kenogen represents a state of latency in the hair cycle.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.6-8

choices.text: Melanin is Absent in Vellus Hair
Vellus Hair Depth extends to the Dermis
Medulla is Thicker in Vellus Hair

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement regarding Types of Hair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medulla is Thicker in Vellus Hair

 

Option C.

  • Medulla is thicker in terminal hair, (NOT vellus hair)

  • Medulla is thicker in vellus hair is incorrect because vellus hair typically lacks a medulla. The medulla, when present, is found in thicker terminal hairs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Melanin is absent in vellus hair: Correct

  • Vellus hair is fine, light-colored, and non-pigmented, which contrasts with terminal hair that contains melanin.

 

Option B. Vellus hair depth extends to the dermis: Correct

  • This is true as the follicles of vellus hair are present in the dermis, although they are not as deep as the follicles of terminal hair.

 

Option D. Lanugo hair is non-medullated: Correct

  • Lanugo hair, which is the fine hair that covers the fetus and is usually shed before or shortly after birth, typically does not have a medulla.
     

  • The term "lanugo" describes the delicate, soft, non medullated, and typically unpigmented hair of the prenatal stage.

  • Normally, between the eighth and ninth month of pregnancy, it is shed in utero.
     

  • Postnatal hair is of two kinds: Vellus & Terminal

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vellus hair is non-pigmented and lacks a medulla, whereas the medulla is found in thicker terminal hairs.
     

  • Lanugo hair is also non-medullated.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.2

choices.text: Hair Follicle Epithelium

questions.text: Which among the following is the primary target of action of androgen in the hair follicle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermal Papilla

 

Option B.

  • The primary target of androgen's action in the hair is the dermal papilla.

 

Dermal Papillae:

  • Androgens exert their effects on Hair Growth and Loss by acting on the Dermal Papillae, which is rich in Androgen Receptors.
  • These structures control the Hair Growth Cycle and are responsible for the changes seen in Androgenetic Alopecia.

 

 

This is due to two crucial characteristics of Dermal Papillae, including:

  1. Androgen Receptors, which are present exclusively in Dermal Papillae.
  2. Expression of Type 2 of 5 ùõº-Reductase Enzyme, which controls Androgen-Dependent Hair Growth.

 

The following are the Effects of Androgens on Hair Growth.

  • It raises the density of cells in the dermal papilla, which promotes the development of hair follicles and pubertal hair growth.
  • It results in male pattern hair loss by shrinking the hair follicle in other vulnerable sites.

 

Clinical Relevance of this Observation:

  • In the dermal papillae, finasteride prevents testosterone from being converted to DHT (Di-Hydro- Testosterone).
  • This stops the Miniaturisation and Progression of alopecia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hair Follicle Epithelium:

  • While androgens influence the hair follicle as a whole, the primary and direct target is not the epithelium, but rather the dermal papillae where the androgen receptors are most concentrated.

 

Option C. Bulb:

  • The hair bulb, which is the lower part of the hair follicle containing the hair matrix, is influenced by the dermal papillae.
  • However, it is not the primary site of androgen action.

 

Option D. Infundibulum:

  • This is the upper part of the hair follicle that extends from the skin surface to the opening of the sebaceous gland.
  • Androgens do not primarily target the infundibulum in altering hair growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dermal papillae are the primary target of androgen action in the hair follicle, playing a crucial role in hair growth cycles and conditions such as androgenetic alopecia.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.4 & 89.5

choices.text: This is called as Anagen Effluvium
It is an example for Diffuse Hair Loss
Hair does not regrow once the Offending Agent is Stopped
Hair Loss finished within 1-2 Months of Chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady diagnosed with Skin malignancy & she underwent chemotherapy, presents with hair loss after 3 weeks of starting of chemotherapy. Identify the INCORRECT statement about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hair does not regrow once the Offending Agent is Stopped.

 

Option C.

  • It is incorrect. Typically, hair regrows after the cessation of chemotherapy, although it may have a different texture or color.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This condition is known as Anagen effluvium. Correct:

  • It is hair loss that occurs during the anagen or growth phase of the hair cycle, commonly induced by chemotherapy.
  • Hair regrows once offending chemotherapy agent is stopped.
  • It is due to the anagen, or proliferating phase of the hair cycle being adversely affected.
  • Following the start of chemotherapy, hair loss usually starts within 1-3 weeks and is finished within 1-2 months.

 

Option B. It is an example for Diffuse Hair Loss. Correct:

  • It is indeed an example of Diffuse hair loss, where hair loss occurs uniformly across the scalp, often because of systemic treatment like chemotherapy.

 

Option D. Hair loss finished within 1-2 months of chemotherapy. Correct:

  • It typically occurs rapidly after the start of chemotherapy and can continue for a short period after the therapy has concluded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chemotherapy-induced hair loss, or Anagen effluvium, is a type of Diffuse hair loss that generally resolves after the completion of chemotherapy, with hair regrowth occurring over time.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.7, 89.48

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented with heavy hair loss for 4 months. She gives a history of suffering with COVID 19, 8 months back. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Telogen Effluvium

 

Option A.

  • Telogen effluvium:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Androgenetic Alopecia. Incorrect:

  • It is characterized by a patterned hair loss and is a genetic condition.
  • It's less likely to be associated with a recent illness.

 

Option C. Alopecia Areata. Incorrect:

  • It usually presents with patchy hair loss and is an autoimmune disorder.
  • The hair loss is not typically diffuse as described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania. Incorrect:

  • It is a hair-pulling disorder, which typically results in irregular areas of broken hairs of varying length, usually not consistent with a history of illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Telogen effluvium is a likely diagnosis in patients presenting with diffuse hair loss following a significant stressor such as illness, in this case, COVID-19.
  • This condition usually resolves spontaneously as the effects of the stressor diminish.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.25

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th Edition Page 1509

choices.text: Exclamation Mark Hair
Alopecia Totalis Denotes Loss of all Scalp Hair
Spontaneous Remission is seen in 10% of the Patients, in case of Limited Alopecia Areata.
Turning White Overnight Phenomenon

questions.text: A patient presented with patchy hair loss. On histological examination, perifollicular lymphocytic infiltration is seen giving swarms of Bees appearance. All the following can be seen associated with this disease EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spontaneous remission is seen in 10% of the patients, in case of limited alopecia areata.

 

Option C.

  • From the clinical & histological clues given in this question, this patient has alopecia areata.
  • Spontaneous remission is seen in 80% of the patients, in case of limited Alopecia areata. (NOT 10% as mentioned in Option C)
  • Alopecia areata is a chronic Auto-immune disease that causes non-scarring patchy hair loss.
     
  • It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals.
     
  • It is Associated with HLA DR4, DR5, DQ3.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Exclamation Mark Hair

  • This refers to short extractable broken hairs which are thinner towards the base as shown in the image below
     

 

Option B. Alopecia Totalis:

  • It means loss of all scalp hair & alopecia universalis means loss of all body hair.

 

Option D. Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata:

  • Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair. Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease.
  • If it advances quickly, sparing white hair, this leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called Turning white overnight.

 

The following image sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia areata is characterized by patchy hair loss, exclamation mark hair, and potential for complete scalp hair loss (alopecia totalis), and while spontaneous remission is common, it occurs in 80% of cases with limited disease.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.28-33

Online resource: https://www.bmj.com/content/347/bmj.f6112

choices.text: Squaric acid dibutylester (SABDE)

questions.text: What is the initial treatment recommended for limited alopecia areata?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intralesional Steroids

 

Option A. Intralesional Steroids:

  • They are the first-line treatment for limited Alopecia areata. They are injected directly into the hairless patches to promote hair regrowth.

 

 

  • This localized treatment minimizes systemic side effects and is effective for patchy hair loss.

 

Intra lesional steroids are the first line treatment in limited alopecia areata.

 

The following treatment options are used in Alopecia Areata.

 

  1. Intralesional steroids - Depot steroid (Triamcinolone acetonide 5–10 mg/ml or Hydrocortisone acetate 25 mg/ml)
  2. If the initial course of treatment is unsuccessful, oral corticosteroids are used as a second line.
  3. Contact immunotherapy via Squaric Acid Di Butyl Ester (SABDE) as a third line management. It functions by applying an allergen to the scalp to cause mild contact dermatitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Oral steroids:

  • They are not recommended as initial therapy for limited Alopecia areata due to the potential for systemic side effects and lack of evidence for superior efficacy compared to less invasive treatments.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine:

  • It is an immunosuppressant that is generally reserved for more severe cases of Alopecia areata or when other treatments have failed, due to its side effect profile and the need for monitoring.

 

Option D. Squaric Acid Dibutylester (SABDE):

  • It is a topical immunotherapy that is sometimes used in Alopecia areata, but it is not considered a first-line treatment and is typically reserved for extensive cases or when other treatments have not worked.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The initial treatment for limited Alopecia areata is intralesional steroids, which are considered first-line due to their efficacy and localized action with minimal systemic effects.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.34

questions.text: All of the following conditions cause Non-Cicatricial Alopecia EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scleroderma

 

Option B.

 

  • It is a condition that leads to changes in the Skin, Blood Vessels, Muscles, and Internal Organs.
  • It can cause Cicatricial (Scarring) Alopecia due to the skin hardening process that Destroys Hair Follicles.

 

Alopecia Areata, Secondary Syphilis & Trichotillomania cause non-scarring alopecia (non-cicatricial).

 

  • Alopecia or Hair Loss can be classified as:

 

  1. Non-Scarring / Non-Cicatricial Alopecia
  2. Scarring / Cicatricial Alopecia

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • It is an autoimmune condition that causes non-cicatricial (non-scarring) alopecia.
  • It presents with round patches of hair loss and does not destroy the hair follicle, thus the hair can regrow.

 

Option C. Secondary Syphilis:

 

  • It can present with "moth-eaten" alopecia, which is a non-cicatricial (non-scarring) alopecia

 

 

  • The hair loss from syphilis does not typically result in permanent follicle destruction and is reversible with treatment.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania (TTM):

 

  • It is a condition caused by the compulsive pulling of one's own hair, leading to non-cicatricial (non-scarring) alopecia.

 

 

Clinical Image of a patient suffering from Trichotillomania (TTM) depicting hairs of varying Lengths

 

  • The hair loss pattern is irregular and can improve with Behavioral Interventions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scleroderma is the condition associated with cicatricial (scarring) alopecia, while Alopecia Areata, Secondary Syphilis, and Trichotillomania are associated with non-cicatricial (non-scarring) alopecia.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 86 Page No 86.17 Chapter 89 Page No 89.41 89.45

choices.text: Slit Skin Smear

questions.text: Which of the following is useful for Diagnosis of Tinea Capitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) KOH Mount

 

Option D.

  • It is the correct answer because Potassium Hydroxide (KOH) preparation is a simple and effective method for diagnosing fungal infections, including tinea capitis.
  • KOH clears the keratin in hair and skin cells, making fungal elements more visible under the microscope.
  • It is useful for the diagnosis of Tinea capitis.
  • The disease may present in a variety of ways, such as scaling with minimal hair loss, discrete patches with infected broken hair appearing as black dots, and kerion-like boggy plaques with pustules.

 

 

  • Although the diagnosis is typically clinical, a KOH mount can be prepared to confirm it.
  • Scrapings from the lesion edge are placed on a slide, and KOH is then added.
  • Then, as shown below, it is examined under a microscope to check for hyphae.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tzanck Smear:

  • It is used for diagnosing vesicular skin diseases like herpes simplex and varicella-zoster virus infections.
  • It is not useful for fungal infections such as tinea capitis.

 

Option B. Gram Stain:

  • It is used primarily to detect bacterial organisms, which are categorized as Gram-positive or Gram-negative based on their cell wall structure.
  • It is not appropriate for the diagnosis of fungal infections like tinea capitis.

 

Option C. Slit Skin Smear:

  • It is commonly used for the diagnosis of leprosy by identifying acid-fast bacilli.
  • It is not used for fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • KOH mount is the diagnostic test of choice for tinea capitis, as it allows for the visualization of fungal hyphae and spores in hair shafts and skin scrapings.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page No 32.8

Image Ref: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Teigne_Kerion.jpg

https://ijdvl.com/skin-scraping-and-a-potassium-hydroxide-mount/

choices.text: Late Age of Onset

questions.text: Bad Prognostic Factors for Alopecia Areata are all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Late Age of Onset

 

Option A.

  • It is not considered a bad prognostic factor for Alopecia areata.
  • In fact, early onset has been associated with a more severe disease course.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ophiasis:

  • It is a pattern of Alopecia areata with hair loss in the shape of a band along the sides and lower back of the scalp and is known to be associated with a poorer prognosis.

 

Option C. Alopecia Totalis:

  • Where there is total hair loss of the scalp, and

 

Option D. Alopecia Universalis:

  • Which is hair loss of the entire body, are both considered to have a poorer prognosis compared to more limited forms of Alopecia areata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Early Age of Onset, Ophiasis Pattern, Alopecia Totalis, and Alopecia Universalis are associated with a poorer prognosis in Alopecia areata, whereas Late Age of Onset is generally not considered a negative prognostic factor.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.28-33

choices.text: DHT (Dihydrotestosterone) is responsible for Follicular Regression
Frontal Hairline is maintained in Female Pattern Hair Loss (FPHL)
Minoxidil has Vasodilatory Function
Finasteride selectively inhibits Type 1, 5 ùõº-reductase within the Hair Follicle

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement regarding Androgenetic Alopecia and its treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Finasteride selectively inhibits Type 1,5 ùõº-reductase within the Hair Follicle.

 

Option D.

  • Finasteride selectively inhibits type 2, 5-alpha reductase, not type 1, within the hair follicle, which is responsible for the conversion of testosterone to the more potent androgen DHT.
  • The disorder, known as Androgenetic Alopecia, is characterised by the Miniaturisation & Reduction of hair follicle production.
  • Male pattern hair loss and female pattern hair loss are the two types.
  • Females may experience male pattern hair loss, and the opposite is also true.
  • Recession of the frontal hairline and vertex thinning are effects of male pattern hair loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DHT (Di Hydro Testosterone):

  • It is implicated in the pathogenesis of Androgenetic alopecia, causing progressive follicular miniaturization and regression.

 

Option B. Female Pattern Hair Loss (FPHL):

  • In Female pattern hair loss (FPHL), the frontal hairline is typically maintained, which is a key feature that distinguishes it from male pattern hair loss.

 

 

Option C. Minoxidil:

  • Minoxidil does have a vasodilatory function, which is thought to improve hair growth by increasing blood flow to the hair follicles.
  • Minoxidil increases Androgen Phase & increases size of the Miniaturized hair Follicle

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Finasteride targets type 2, 5-alpha Reductase in the treatment of Androgenetic Alopecia, while Minoxidil works through vasodilation, and in FPHL, the frontal hairline remains intact.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.9-17

choices.text: Bulge of Hair Follicle
Basal Layer of Interfollicular Epidermis
Base of Sebaceous Glands
Base of Apocrine Glands

questions.text: All of the following is the location of stem cells in the skin EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The Base of Apocrine Glands

 

Option D.

  • It is not a recognized site for stem cells in the skin. Apocrine glands are sweat glands that are mainly found in the Axillary (Armpit) and Genital Areas.
  • They are associated with hair follicles, but their base does not serve as a niche for skin stem cells.
  • Skin stem cells are known to reside in specific niches where they remain quiescent until activated by physiological needs.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The bulge region of the hair follicle:

  • It is a well-characterized niche for stem cells.
  • It houses a population of multipotent stem cells that can give rise to the various cellular lineages of the skin, including hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and epidermis.

 

Option B. The basal layer of the interfollicular epidermis:

  • It is another recognized site for stem cells. These cells are responsible for the continuous regeneration of the epidermis.

 

Option C. The base of sebaceous glands:

  • It is associated with the hair follicle, also contains stem cells.
  • These stem cells can differentiate into sebaceous gland cells and contribute to the repair of the epidermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The locations of stem cells within the skin -  Stem cells are located in the bulge of hair follicles, the basal layer of the interfollicular epidermis, and the base of sebaceous glands, but not at the base of apocrine glands. 

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 2 Page No 2.44

choices.text: Alopecia Areata
Anagen Effluvium
Telogen Effluvium
Androgenic Alopecia

questions.text:
A 27-Year-Old Male presents to the Dermatology Clinic with a complaint of Hair Loss over the past few weeks. He reports that the Hair Loss is Painless. On Examination, Patchy Hair Loss is observed on the Scalp, as shown in the image provided.

 

 

The Exclamation Mark Sign is Positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alopecia Areata

 

Option A.

  • The clinical presentation described and illustrated is characteristic of Alopecia Areata, an Autoimmune condition that causes Patchy Hair Loss.
  • The positive Exclamation Mark sign, where hairs are Easily pulled out at the Periphery of the patch and are Narrow at the base than at the Distal End, is often associated with alopecia areata.
     

 

  • Exclamation mark hairs are pointed with broken arrows in the above image

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anagen Effluvium:

  • This typically occurs due to the interruption of the active growth phase of hair follicles, often as a result of chemotherapy or radiation.

 

Option C. Telogen Effluvium:

  • This is characterized by diffuse hair shedding, often following a stressful event, and does not typically present with patchy hair loss.

 

Option D. Androgenic Alopecia:

  • It is also known as male pattern baldness, is characterized by a receding hairline and thinning of the hair on the crown.
  • It does not present with patchy, well-demarcated areas of hair loss.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia Areata recognized by its classic presentation of Patchy, Well-Demarcated Areas of Hair Loss on the Scalp and a positive Exclamation Mark Sign.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.28-33

Online Resource: https://www.bmj.com/content/347/bmj.f6112

https://ijdvl.com/relevance-of-trichoscopy-in-the-differential-diagnosis-of-alopecia-a-cross-sectional-study-from-north-india/

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presenting with Non-Scarring Alopecia in the Vertex Region of the Head and exhibiting histological findings of Hair Loss with haemorrhage into the Follicular Areas and Mild Perinuclear Lymphocytic Infiltrate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichotillomania

 

Option D.

  • From the given clinical features & histopathological features, diagnosis is Trichotillomania (TTM) / Trichotillosis / Hair pulling disorder.

 

Clinical Features Suggestive of Trichotillomania in the Clinical Vignette:

 

  • The clinical history revealing non scarring alopecia in the vertex region (Hair pulling and plucking is commonest from the scalp)

 

 

  • No signs of inflammation

  • Perifollicular hemorrhage

 

Diagnostic Criteria for TTM include:

 

  • Recurrent pulling out of one‚Äôs own hair resulting in non-scarring hair loss.

  • An increasing sense of tension immediately before pulling out the hair or when attempting to resist the behaviour.

  • Pleasure, gratification, or relief when pulling out the hair.

  • The disturbance is not better accounted for by another mental disorder.

  • The disturbance provokes clinically marked distress and/or impairment in occupational, social, or other areas of functioning.

  • Histopathology: No / Minimal inflammation

  • Mild lymphocytic infiltrate can be seen in TTM too.

  • Peribulbar hemorrhage - due to trauma from plucking of hair.

  • Intraepithelial and Perifollicular hemorrhage and intrafollicular pigment casts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alopecia Areata:

  • While it is characterized by non-scarring alopecia and can have lymphocytic infiltrate around the hair follicles, the hemorrhage is not a typical feature.

  • Generally, presents as well-defined patches of hair loss.

 

Option B. Telogen Effluvium:

  • It manifests as a diffuse or generalized hair shedding from the entire scalp rather than localized patches.

  • It's commonly due to stress, certain medications, or illnesses.

  • Histopathology would not typically show hemorrhage or the specific perinuclear infiltrate described.

 

Option C. Tinea Infection:

  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp.

  • It usually presents with scaling and possibly broken-off hairs.

  • Histological examination would show evidence of fungal elements (hyphae and spores) rather than hemorrhage or lymphocytic infiltrate.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a young patient with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region and histological findings of hair loss with follicular hemorrhage and mild lymphocytic infiltrate, the diagnosis is likely Trichotillomania.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 86 & 89, Page Nos 86.17 & 89.31

Fitzpatrick‚Äôs Dermatology 9th Edition Page No: 1695

choices.text: Stem of the Hair Follicle

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents to the dermatology outpatient department with a complaint of a painful, boggy swelling on the scalp that has developed over the past few days. On examination, the child's hair is easily pluckable, and regional lymph nodes are palpably swollen. Culture of the lesion yields growth of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. Which of the following represents the location beyond which this fungus DOES NOT typically penetrate a hair follicle in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adamson’s Fringe

 

Option C.

Diagnosis of the above case scenario is Tinea capitis:

 

  • In cases of tinea capitis caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes, the fungus invades the hair shaft but does not typically penetrate beyond Adamson’s fringe.

 

 

  • Adamson's Fringe is a critical landmark within the hair follicle, identified as the point where the hair shaft completes its keratinization.
  • It is named after Horatio George Adamson, a British dermatologist who first described it in 1895.
  • This fringe marks the upper margin of the keratogenous zone where the transition from nucleated to anucleated keratin occurs, signifying the end of the inner root sheath's Henle's layer and the cuticle's complete keratinization.

 

 

  • In the case of Tinea capitis, a dermatophytic infection, the presence of fungi is confined to this zone.
  • The infection does not extend beyond this point into the lower regions of the hair shaft or the bulb of the follicle.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Isthmus:

  • It is the part of the hair follicle between the entry of the sebaceous gland duct and the arrector pili muscle insertion.

 

Option B. The Infundibulum:

  • It is the upper part of the hair follicle extending from the skin surface to the opening of the sebaceous gland.
  • Fungal penetration in tinea capitis usually involves the infundibulum.

 

Option D. The stem of the hair follicle:

  • It includes the regions above Adamson's fringe, which are typically involved in fungal infections like tinea capitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The limit of fungal penetration in the hair follicle in tinea capitis, which is typically Adamson’s fringe.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology - 4th Edition Page No 1520

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th Edition Page No: Fig 4.1

Online Resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3129117/

choices.text: Androgenetic Alopecia (Male pattern Baldness)
Androgenetic Alopecia (Female pattern Baldness)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with diffuse hair thinning over the crown and frontal scalp without any signs of inflammation. The Frontal hairline is receding backwards which is prominent in the temporal area, and the exclamation mark sign is negative. Based on the presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Androgenetic Alopecia (Male pattern Baldness)

 

Option C.

  • The clinical features described are characteristic of androgenetic alopecia, also known as male pattern baldness.

 

 

  • It typically presents with a receding frontal hairline and diffuse thinning over the crown and frontal scalp, more pronounced in the temporal areas, without signs of inflammation.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alopecia Areata:

  • It is usually characterized by patchy, non-scarring hair loss and may occasionally present with the exclamation mark sign, which is not observed in this case.

 

Option B. Anagen Effluvium:

  • It is typically a result of an insult to the hair follicle during the anagen phase, often from chemotherapy, which leads to widespread hair loss, not a receding hairline.

 

Option D. Androgenetic Alopecia (Female pattern Baldness):

  • This generally presents with diffuse thinning over the vertex with the frontal hairline being maintained, which differs from the pattern seen in this male patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Androgenetic Alopecia (Male pattern Baldness) by recognizing the classic presentation of a receding frontal hairline, particularly in the temporal areas, and diffuse thinning over the crown and frontal scalp, without signs of inflammation.

 

Ref: Online resources

  • ccjm.org - Male and female pattern hair loss: Treatable and worth ...
  • frontiersin.org - Female Pattern Hair Loss in Female and Male
  • ncbi.nlm.nih.gov - Female pattern hair loss: Current treatment concepts
  • ncbi.nlm.nih.gov - Classifications of Patterned Hair Loss: A Review
  • sciencedirect.com - Prevalence of Male and Female Pattern Hair Loss in ...

 

Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.14, 89.17

choices.text: Exclamation Mark Hair Sign
Pitting of the Nails

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the clinic with sudden, patchy hair loss over the past three months. A diagnosis of Alopecia areata is made. Which of the following findings is NOT associated with alopecia areata?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Geographic Tongue

 

Option D:

  • Geographic tongue is NOT seen in Alopecia areata, it can be seen in association with various conditions, particularly:
  1. Pustular Psoriasis,
  2. Fissured Tongue,
  3. Atopic Dermatitis,
  4. Allergic Contact Dermatitis,
  5. Asthma,
  6. Reactive Arthritis

 

 

Geographic tongue

 

Alopecia areata:

  • It is commonly associated with nail changes like pitting, as well as with systemic conditions such as atopy, including atopic dermatitis.
  • Exclamation mark hairs are a classic Dermoscopy finding in alopecia areata, indicative of hairs that break off a few millimetres from the scalp.
  • However, geographic tongue, characterized by map-like patterns on the tongue's surface, is not typically associated with alopecia areata.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Exclamation Mark Hair Sign:

  • It is a characteristic feature often observed at the edges of alopecia patches.

 

Option B. Atopy:

  • It includes a range of allergic conditions such as asthma, eczema, and allergic rhinitis, can be associated with alopecia areata.

 

Option C. Nail Pitting:

  • It is a common finding in patients with alopecia areata and may sometimes be the first sign of this disease.
  • Geometrically arranged Fine, Superficial, Regular Pits

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia areata is associated with exclamation mark hair sign, atopy, and nail pitting but not with geographic tongue.

 

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.14, 89.17

Online resources: https://dermnetnz.org/topics/geographic-tongue

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in Non-Scarring Alopecia from the following options.

 

  1. Alopecia Areata
  2. Telogen Effluvium
  3. Androgenic Alopecia
  4. Frontal Fibrosing Alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

 

Option B. 1, 2, and 3

 

Androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium (1, 2, and 3) are responsible for non-scarring alopecia. On the other hand, frontal fibrosing alopecia falls under the category of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

 

  1. Alopecia Areata
  • It is an autoimmune condition that causes patchy hair loss.
  • The hair follicles are not destroyed and can regrow hair if the underlying inflammation is treated, thus it is considered non-scarring.

 

  1. Telogen Effluvium
  • It is a form of temporary hair loss that typically occurs after stress, a shock, or a traumatic event.
  • The hair loss is diffuse and does not involve scarring of the scalp.

 

  1. Androgenic Alopecia
  • It is also known as male or female pattern baldness, is characterized by a progressive thinning of the hair in a typical pattern.
  • The condition is non-scarring as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner and shorter hairs but are not destroyed.

 

  1. Frontal Fibrosing Alopecia
  • Type of Hair Loss: Scarring alopecia primarily affecting the frontal hairline and eyebrows.
  • Predominantly Affects: Postmenopausal women.
  • Symptoms: Progressive hairline recession, eyebrow loss, and sometimes body hair loss.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Frontal Hairline Recession: Gradual and symmetrical.
    • Eyebrow Thinning: Outer third of eyebrows commonly affected.

 

 

    •  
    • Perifollicular Erythema: Redness around hair follicles.

 

  • Potential Causes: Autoimmune or hormonal factors may play a role.
  • Treatment:
    •  
    • Medical Approaches: Topical or systemic corticosteroids, anti-inflammatory medications.
    • Cosmetic Solutions: Wigs, eyebrow makeup, tattoos.
  • Prognosis: Hair loss is often permanent; early intervention may slow progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-Scarring Alopecia, which allows for the possibility of hair regrowth, includes Alopecia Areata, Telogen Effluvium, and Androgenic Alopecia.
  • Frontal Fibrosing Alopecia is associated with Scarring Alopecia.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 32.24, 32.39-40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.7, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20, 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

questions.text: Match the items of Column A with Column B
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-e, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a, 5-b, 6-f

 

Explanation of each option:

 

  1. Loss of Frontal-Parietal Hairline - e) Androgenic Alopecia
    • Androgenic alopecia commonly manifests as a receding hairline at the temples and can progress to affect the Frontal-Parietal Region.

 

  1. Chemotherapy-Induced Hair Loss - d) Anagen Effluvium
    • Anagen effluvium typically occurs due to chemotherapy which affects rapidly dividing hair follicle cells, leading to widespread hair loss.

 

  1. Hairs of varying Lengths in Alopecia Patch - c) Trichotillomania
    • Trichotillomania, a hair-pulling disorder, results in patches of hair loss with broken hairs of various lengths.

 

  1. Peribulbar Inflammation - a) Alopecia Areata
    • Alopecia areata is characterized by immune-mediated peribulbar inflammation described as swarm of Bees Appearance around Hair Follicles, leading to Patchy Hair Loss.

 

  1. Stress-Induced Hair Loss - b) Telogen Effluvium
    • Telogen effluvium is often triggered by stress, causing diffuse hair shedding when hairs enter the telogen (resting) phase prematurely.

 

  1. Scarring Alopecia - f) Lichen Planopilaris
    • Lichen planopilaris is a type of scarring alopecia that results in permanent hair loss due to inflammation that destroys the hair follicle

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 32.24, 32.39-40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.7, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20, 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting Hair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichothiodystrophy

 

Option C.

  • The given clinical image of hair seen under polarizing microscopy reveals tiger tail banding (alternating light and dark bands) characteristic of trichothiodystrophy.

 

Trichothiodystrophy/PIBIDS Syndrome: Autosomal Recessive Condition

  • Photosensitivity (unlike XP, has NO increased skin cancer risk)
  • Ichthyosis
  • Brittle hair (short/sparse on scalp/brows/lashes w/alternating light and dark bands on polarizing light microscopy (“tiger-tail” abnormality)
  • Intellectual impairment and ataxia
  • Decreased fertility/hypogonadism
  • Short stature

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Trichorrhexis Nodosa

  • It is associated with Node Formation.
  • It may be seen in Arginosuccinic Aciduria.
  • Characterized by classical appearance as if Two Paint Brushes are rubbing against each other described as Thrust Paintbrush Appearance.

 

 

Option B. Trichorrhexis Invaginata:

  • Also known as Bamboo hair having Golf tee or Ball & Socket appearance, in which the distal part of the hair shaft is compressed against the dilated and cupped proximal shaft.
  • Seen in Netherton’s syndrome.

 

 

Option D: Monilethrix:

  • Beaded hair seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "Tigertail" banding of hair under polarized light microscopy is indicative of trichothiodystrophy, a condition characterized by brittle hair with reduced sulfur content and potentially associated with multi system involvement.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 1537

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Pages 65.33, 68.21, 78.10 89.53-54

Online resources: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Hair-disorders-with-specific-appearances_tbl1_51502302

choices.text: The Phase of Activity & Growth
The Phase of Transition
The Phase of Resting
The Phase of Degeneration

questions.text: Anagen Phase of the Hair Follicle indicates?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The Phase of Activity & Growth

 

Option A.

  • The Anagen Phase is characterized by the Active Growth of the Hair Follicle.
  • During this phase, Cells in the Hair Root are dividing rapidly, contributing to the lengthening of the hair shaft.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The phase of transition:

  • Incorrect because this describes the catagen phase (involution), a transitional stage where the hair follicle begins to shut down.

 

Option C. The phase of resting

  • Incorrect because this describes the telogen phase, where the hair follicle is at rest and the hair shaft does not grow.

 

 

Option D. The phase of degeneration

Incorrect because this is not a recognized phase of the hair growth cycle. The Exogen Phase could be considered a phase of shedding or the release of hair, but it is not typically referred to as degeneration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anagen phase is the period of active hair growth in the hair follicle life cycle.

 

Ref: Bolognia Dermatology 3rd Edition Page No 1073
